title: PuTTY saved sessions with CJK characters fail to display and connect
author: yongwoo1
body_snippet:
- Version: 1.76.11.40527

- Issue:

When a saved PuTTY session name contains Korean characters, the session name is not displayed correctly, and the corresponding session cannot be connected.


- Suspected Cause:

There appears to be an issue with decoding session names. This problem is likely not limited to Korean but may affect all CJK characters.

@yongwoo1 Thank you for testing. The issue is confirmed: on .NET 10, CodePagesEncodingProvider must be registered at startup for non-UTF-8 codepages (EUC-KR/CP949) to work. Without it, the decoder fails silently.

Fix applied:
- Encoding.RegisterProvider(CodePagesEncodingProvider.Instance) added to app startup
- Added try/catch fallback in PuttySessionNameDecoder

Will update once a testable build is available.

comments.snippet: Confirmed: on .NET 10 without CodePagesEncodingProvider registered, Encoding.GetEncoding(949) fails and CJK session names are not decoded. Fix in v1.80.0: registered the provider at app startup and added fallback in the decoder.

comments.snippet:
@yongwoo1 Thank you for testing v1.79.0. The percent-encoded display (`%BC%AD%B9%F6%20%BC%B3%C4%A1`) means the URL-decoding step is not applying the correct codepage (EUC-KR / codepage 949) to convert the bytes back to Korean characters.

I'm investigating this now in the v1.80.0 branch. The fix needs to:
1. Detect that the percent-encoded bytes are EUC-KR (not UTF-8)
2. Decode using `Encoding.GetEncoding(949)` after `CodePagesEncodingProvider` registration
